statement.para: If V=\span(S), then S is a basis of V if and only if removing any \Vect{v} from S yields a set S' which fails to span V.

proof.para:
Consider first the case where S is a basis of V. If we remove a vector \Vect{v} from S, we obtain a set S whose
span does not contain \Vect{v}
Look up this fact
. Thus S' fails to span V.

Conversely, suppose removing any vector \Vect{v} from V yields a set S' which fails to span V. We need to show that S is linearly independent. We argue by contradiction: Suppose S is linearly dependent. Then there is a vector \Vect{v} in S which is a linear combination of the remaining vectors in S. So form S' by removing \Vect{v} from S. We find \span(S)= \span(S'), contradicting the assumption of the proposition.

We have shown that the assumption that S is not linearly independent leads to a contradiction to the hypothesis of this result. This assumption is, therefore, false. Consequently S a linearly independent spanning set of V; i.e. it is a basis of V.
